description: Chiswick House and Gardens is one of the most glorious examples of 18th-century British architecture and landscaping with over 300 years of discovery, inspiration and delight.

factsheet.heading: Visit
paragraphs: Chiswick House and the Kitchen Garden are open Thursday to Sunday, 10am-4pm until 30 October 2022.
Our Gardens are open daily, all year round from 7am to dusk.

Entry to the grade-I listed 18th century villa. Your ticket includes a free explorer map and an audio-guide (adult and children's guides available), plus guided tours and family trails.
House and Kitchen Garden tickets also include {Paradise in the Sun} Or a garden of all sorts of pleasant flowers - an immersive audio experience in the Kitchen Garden.

Adult House & Kitchen Garden - £11.00
Child House & Kitchen Garden (Under 5s go free) - £5.50
Family (with 1 adults) House & Kitchen Garden - £16.00
Jobseekers & Students House & Kitchen Garden - £5.50
Use code CHGT-OHFEST-22 for 25% off your ticket during the Open House!
Book online at tinyurl.com/28wpawej or buy tickets on the door.

House only or Kitchen Garden only tickets available. Discounts available for English Heritage members and Art Fund members. Please see our website for more information.

factsheet.heading: Spotlight Talks
paragraphs: Join out Visitor Experience Assistants every Thursday to Sunday at 2pm to learn about items from the collection!
Learn about James I, Charles I, Georgiana Duchess of Devonshire, and Alexander Pope, and discover why their portraits appear in Chiswick House.
These talks are included in your ticket. Mention Open House on the door for 25% off!

factsheet.heading: {Paradise in the Sun} Or a garden of all sorts of pleasant flowers
paragraphs: ‘{Paradise in the Sun} Or a garden of all sorts of pleasant flowers’ is an immersive audio experience in the Kitchen Garden celebrating community and the sensory power of nature.

Part hypnosis, part therapy, {Paradise in the Sun} Or a garden of all sorts of pleasant flowers is a celebration of the joy of community and belonging and the sensory pleasures of being in nature. The immersive audio experience invites you to slow down, disconnect from the ‘noise’ of city living and instead reconnect with the natural environment.
Admission to {Paradise in the Sun} Or a garden of all sorts of pleasant flowers is included in your House & Kitchen Garden ticket, or a Kitchen Garden only ticket. Open Thursday to Sunday, 10am-4pm

factsheet.heading: Black Chiswick through History
paragraphs: Black Chiswick through History is an ongoing community research project which aims to look more deeply at our collections.

Helping to redefine how we understand our local history through a diversity of voices and perspectives. We work closely with our local community to explore, question and respond to our collection, and strive to make visible these shared histories to all who visit Chiswick House and Gardens.

Since 2021 we have been working with Chiswick School and Hogarth Youth and Community Centre. Focusing on six objects, new research drew out stories of people, places and experiences, related to Black history, with both global and local connections. Inspired by this research and their own diverse experiences and background, the young people produced a series of thoughtful responses to the collection. You can see their creative responses on display in the house, enriching the interpretation for all our visitors.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The third Earl of Burlington (1694-1753) designed the elegant Classical villa seen today, drawing inspiration from his 'grand tours' of Italy. It was originally located in a modest estate purchased by his grandfather, next to an existing Jacobean house.

The villa was more a showcase for the arts rather than a home, and it provided a spectacular venue for entertaining. During his travels Burlington met the architect William Kent and invited him to collaborate on the design of the villa. William Kent also designed the gardens and started the influential 'English Landscape Movement'.

By the 1770s Chiswick had passed to the fifth Duke of Devonshire who initiated a series of major changes to both house and garden, demolishing the earlier Jacobean house and adding new wings to the villa. These were subsequently removed in the 1950s.

As the home of successive members of Lord Burlington's family, including Georgiana, Duchess of Devonshire, Chiswick House has welcomed scores of significant guests over the years, including the musician Handel, the politician Charles James Fox, Queen Victoria and Prince Albert.

In the 1950s Chiswick House was passed to the Ministry of Works, via Middlesex Council, and a much needed restoration campaign was undertaken. The villa has been cared for by English Heritage since 1984, who, with the Chiswick House and Gardens Trust, set up in 2005, embarked on a major restoration programme which breathed new life into the House and wider Gardens.

factsheet.heading: Chiswick House LEGO® brick model
paragraphs: Using more than 50,000 bricks and taking two years to build, the Chiswick House Friends, in conjunction with Brick Galleria Ltd, present an incredible LEGO® brick model of Chiswick House.

This model illustrates the dramatic architectural changes that Chiswick House has undergone in its c.300-year history, with the LEGO® brick mode showing the addition of two wing buildings which were demolished in the late 18th century. Taking place inside Chiswick House, in the Summer Parlor, you can see it for yourself.
Alongside the model is an area for younger visitors to build their own LEGO® creations inspired by the house and gardens.
Admission to see the Chiswick House LEGO® brick model is included in your House & Kitchen Garden ticket, or a House only ticket.
